title: Vitamin D and Respiratory Infection Risk

intent.decision_context: My doctor suggested vitamin D supplements for my kid who keeps getting colds. I want to see what the actual research says before I decide.
intent.question_draft: Does vitamin D supplementation reduce respiratory infections in children?

papers.title: Vitamin D supplementation to prevent acute respiratory tract infections: systematic review and meta-analysis of individual participant data
papers.abstract: Vitamin D supplementation reduced the risk of acute respiratory tract infection among all participants (adjusted odds ratio 0.88, 95% confidence interval 0.81 to 0.96). Protective effects were seen in those receiving daily or weekly vitamin D without additional bolus doses (0.81, 0.72 to 0.91) and among those with baseline 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels below 25 nmol/L (0.30, 0.17 to 0.53).
papers.witness_line: Large meta-analysis found vitamin D cuts respiratory infection risk, especially in people who were deficient to start with.

papers.title: Effect of Vitamin D3 Supplementation on Upper Respiratory Tract Infections in Healthy Adults: The VIDARIS Randomized Controlled Trial
papers.abstract: Monthly administration of 100,000 IU of vitamin D did not reduce the incidence or severity of upper respiratory tract infections in healthy adults.
papers.witness_line: Monthly high-dose vitamin D did nothing for healthy adults who were not deficient. Dosing schedule and baseline levels matter.

papers.title: Vitamin D supplementation for the prevention of acute respiratory tract infection: a randomized, double-blinded trial among young Finnish men
papers.abstract: Daily vitamin D supplementation (400 IU) in young Finnish military men did not significantly reduce the number of days absent from duty due to respiratory infection compared with placebo.
papers.witness_line: Low-dose daily vitamin D in young healthy men showed no significant benefit. Dose may have been too low.

claims.text: Vitamin D supplementation reduces the risk of respiratory infections, but the effect depends heavily on baseline vitamin D levels and dosing frequency.
People who are vitamin D deficient (below 25 nmol/L) get the most benefit from supplementation.
Daily or weekly dosing works better than monthly bolus doses for preventing infections.
Healthy adults with normal vitamin D levels may see little to no benefit.

synthesis.brief_markdown:
# Vitamin D and Respiratory Infections: What the Papers Say

You asked whether vitamin D supplements can help your kid get fewer colds. Here is what the research actually shows.

## The short version

It depends on whether your kid is vitamin D deficient.

## What the papers say

A large meta-analysis of over 10,000 people (PMID: 28202713) found that vitamin D supplementation does reduce respiratory infection risk overall. But the benefit was strongest for people who were deficient to begin with. For people with very low levels (below 25 nmol/L), the risk dropped by about 70%.

However, two other trials found no benefit in healthy adults who were not deficient (PMID: 34607774, 30675873). Monthly high doses did not help. Low daily doses in healthy young men did not help either.

## What we infer (with receipts)

1. If your kid's vitamin D is low, supplementation is likely to help. [PMID: 28202713]
2. Daily or weekly dosing is better than monthly mega-doses. [PMID: 28202713, 34607774]
3. If vitamin D levels are already normal, don't expect supplements to be a magic shield. [PMID: 34607774, 30675873]

## What to do

Ask your doctor to check your kid's vitamin D level first. That blood test is the receipt that matters. If the level is low, daily supplementation has good evidence behind it. If the level is normal, save your money.

## Confidence: Medium

The meta-analysis is strong, but the subgroup finding (deficient people benefit most) needs more direct trials in children specifically.

cross_examination.change_your_mind: A large RCT in vitamin-D-sufficient children showing clear reduction in respiratory infections would change the conclusion that supplementation mainly helps the deficient.
cross_examination.rival_explanation: The benefit seen in deficient populations could reflect correction of immune dysfunction rather than a direct antiviral effect of vitamin D. The mechanism matters for whether supplementation is the right intervention vs. dietary/lifestyle changes.
cross_examination.confidence_justification: Strong meta-analysis supports the main claim, but contradicting trials in non-deficient populations limit generalizability. The papers studied adults, not children specifically.

next_sprint: Find pediatric-specific vitamin D and respiratory infection trials
Look for dose-response studies in children
Check if there are trials measuring baseline vitamin D before intervention
